posts.name: Jeffrey Davis
posts.cooked:
So, with the starting line being on the open field, how are you tackling telling your robot it’s starting position?

In the past we used fixed locations and when placing the robot on the field it just needed to be set up precisely. However, this year there isn’t anything to push the robot up against to make sure the starting position is perfectly consistent.

How are you handling this? My thoughts were to have the robot see apriltags on start up. Is this reliable enough? Do we need to get a measuring tape out and measure where we put the robot on the lines? Is there some other solution?
Apriltags worked decently for us last year. I think we’re going to go that route again.

posts.name: Jeffrey Davis
posts.cooked: Ok. Do you try to get two of them visible? I’m thinking some part of the reef tags and the barge might be visible. I’m not sure about the barge though.

posts.name: Pedro Braga
posts.cooked: Quick note here, you start under(ish) the barge. You would be looking at reef and source tags.

posts.name: Jeffrey Davis
posts.cooked: Thanks. Those are pretty far away, I suppose while it’s sitting there at boot up before auto starts it can be taking a bunch of samples and get fairly accurate. Does that sound about right?

posts.name: Justin Buist
posts.cooked: Vision here too. It’s hilarious to watch it work on our field. Robot thinks it’s at 0,0 when it starts, vision starts correcting that, and boom, it’s showing us right where it is on the test field.
Nope- our vision couldn’t do more than one tag last year! We’d just make sure it saw a tag as we roughly aligned it.
